title: How did so many soldiers survive the trenches in WW1? - Quora

response.answer_text: The simple answer is that, as the other answers have suggested, not every soldier was on the front lines all the time. Most of the time your battalion would be rotated off of the front line, to the support echelons. After a month of front-line duty, your battalion would be rested. While you were actually at the front, the majority of your time would be spent keeping your head down and just holding the position; the enemy would be mostly doing the same. When there was no major offensive in progress, life in the trenches could be pretty mundane. The major threat to life and limb was taking part in the sporadic assaults which came along relatively infrequently. If you weren’t on the front at that specific time, you were actually pretty safe.

You had enormous casualties during a big attack. At the Somme this mounted to 55.000 in 2 days. That made the count rise. But even on a quiet day due to artillery fire, snipers, raids etc it mounted to many hundreds. War is never a safe place.But trenches even with all the problems provided some safety.

Not everyone was on the front line. Many served behind the lines, building roads, bringing in supplies etc. Keeping your head down was a good start, as was never volunteering for anything. Think it through, if fighting was a guaranteed death sentence, then no-one would fight.
Trenches were in a zig-zag pattern to prevent explosions from getting past the first corner. Trenches were a safe place to be as they had people positioned at trenches sometimes for years.

You were okay as long as you were not on the front line trenches. Most of the time you would have been in the rear trenches. These places were repetitively “safe”. However if you were stationed on the front for that short period you actually were in a great deal of danger. Once you were on the front it was all look apart from a few little things you had to hope you didn’t go over the top.
this was especially true for Germany because their trenches had 90 degree angles unlike the allied powers. a right angled trench has more ability to stop a shock wave from killing soldiers.
